items.title: MOEX: Replace data from all boards to the data from the main board
items.body:
Loading data for Moscow exchange returns info from all of the boards and trading modes. 
```
import pandas_datareader as pdr
pdr.DataReader('sber', 'moex', '2020-07-02', '2020-07-02')
```
The code returns 9 rows for each board (trading mode) for the same date. 
It seems to be better if pdr could return data from the main board only (for each ticker). It would lead to less misunderstanding the results.

I also would like to try this as my first PR

items.title: Odd test variations based on download source
items.body:
When 0.9.0 was released I saw some extra test failures compared to rc1. I have since found that the test results from github tag of 0.9.0 are different than the 0.9.0 release available from pypi.

Comparing the tarball from github and pypi, I see `setup.cfg` varies in formatting (spaces/tabs), while `_version.py` has >500 lines different. As the shorter `_version.py` should be output from the repo script, I don't expect either should cause variations in tests.

This is running on FreeBSD 12.1 amd64

[0.9.0-github](http://shaneware.biz/freebsddebugdata/pandas-datareader/pandas-datareader-0.9.0-github.txt)
1 failed, 113 passed, 56 skipped, 3 xfailed, 1 xpassed

[0.9.0-pypi](http://shaneware.biz/freebsddebugdata/pandas-datareader/pandas-datareader-0.9.0-pypi.txt)
1 failed, 109 passed, 56 skipped, 3 xfailed, 1 xpassed, 1 warnings, 4 error

The v0.9.0 release candidate is now available.  

You can test with pip using

```
pip install pandas-datareader==0.9.0rc1 --pre --upgrade
```

Please find any issues as soon as possible.

items.title: Link to Quandl free dbs is not correct, it should be changed to the following
items.body:
Link to free dbs on Quandl should be changed.

On this page:  https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/blob/master/docs/source/remote_data.rst, the section on Quandl has url: https://blog.quandl.com/free-data-on-quandl, as the location to access free data.  **This is not correct.**  

The correct url for Quandl free dbs is currently at https://www.quandl.com/search?filters=%5B%22Free%22%5D

items.title: Timeout not actually used
items.body:
I noticed my downloader hung forever. I dug through the code and it looks like the timeout parameter isn't actually passed the request call.

https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/blob/09ab475788daee235e0a7d238607cf674e1c19c7/pandas_datareader/base.py#L142

Pretty sure the fix is just:

```
- response = self.session.get(url, params=params, headers=headers)
+ response = self.session.get(url, params=params, headers=headers, timeout=self.timeout)
```

items.title: Unable to add new columns to the created DataFrame
items.body:
I am still trying to figure out if this is an issue specific to this package or pandas in general, however when I pull data into a DataFrame using pandas-datareader via Jupyter Notebook, I am unable to add a column to it without getting a `NoneType is not iterable` error. I have confirmed that it is not the data going into the new column that causes the problem but rather the act of creating the column itself through indexing. Here is an example, and here is the link to the [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61993941/nonetype-error-when-trying-to-create-new-column-from-existing-columns-with-panda) and [Reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/learnpython/comments/gq0516/unable_to_create_new_column_from_existing_columns/) threads that contain the full Error Traceback.

```
fb = pdr.DataReader("FB","yahoo",datetime(2012,5,12),datetime(2020,5,25))
fb['MA10'] = fb['Close'].rolling(10).mean()
```
The last line causes an error, however after some deduction:
I get an error just for typing
`fb['MA10'] = fb['Close']`
whereas just
`fb['Close']=fb['Open']`
does not yield a problem as both are existing columns, however I don't want to manually create a new column every time.

Thanks for any help in advance

I was attempting to download data to make sense of adjusted prices.

To download the split and dividend data from Yahoo, I used 

`pandas_datareader.yahoo.actions.YahooActionReader (ticker, start, end, get_actions=True)`

and 

`pandas_datareader.yahoo.daily.YahooDailyReader(ticker, start, end, get_actions=True)`

Both of them seemed receiving the data fine, however, when converting the data to DataFrame both run into the same error:

items.title: stooq.com - Problem getting data when symbol name ends with ".*"
items.body:
First, thanks for the great module!

When getting data for symbol that ends with .* (CLX19.F)  `.US` is added to symbol, since `f`
is not present in the `["de", "hk", "hu", "jp", "uk", "us"]` array

This works (ohlc timeseries is returned):
`curl "https://stooq.com/q/d/l/?s=CLX19.F&d1=20190101&d2=20190930&i=d"`

This returns `No data`:
`curl "https://stooq.com/q/d/l/?s=CLX19.F.US&d1=20190101&d2=20190930&i=d"`

Workaround would be to add `"f"` in the array where check is being made

https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/blob/48a538c14041bd166a4d138dd3ee372e76f6d2ab/pandas_datareader/stooq.py#L45-L51


I can provide PR with aforementioned workaround.

items.title: AlphaVantage inconsistent index handling for timeseries
items.body:
API documentation describes index values as ```string```

https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/blob/master/pandas_datareader/av/time_series.py#L15

while processes as ```datetime```

https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/blob/master/pandas_datareader/av/time_series.py#L85

The unit test sends it in as ```datetime```

https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/blob/master/pandas_datareader/tests/av/test_av_time_series.py#L41

but validates results as ```string```

The following snippet was working fine until I updated pandas-datareader:

```python3
start = datetime.datetime(1990, 5, 16)
```

items.title: Yahoo dividend adjustments
items.body:
I bumped into this while fixing tests for https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/pull/650

test_yahoo::TestYahoo::test_yahoo_DataReader assumes that Yahoo does not by default adjust dividends for splits.

It looks like yahoo has changed this logic. I can see unadjusted dividends on the Nasdaq page and adjusted dividends on the Yahoo page.

Taking the AAPL example there was a cash dividend of 3.29 (Nasdaq site) on 8 May 2014.
There was then a 1/7 stock split on 09 Jun 2014.
Yahoo records this 8 May dividend as $0.47 (= 3.29 / 7), so yahoo appears to be making dividend adjustments for splits by default.

Within daily.py yahoo.pandas_datareader we have the parameter adjust_dividends: bool, default false. If you set adjust_dividends = True then it'll assume that Yahoo has not made this adjustment and will try to adjust for the dividends a second time. Unadjusted divi = 3.29, yahoo adjusted divi = 3.29 / 7 = 0.47, but then pandas_datareader will adjust this again to 0.47 / 7 = 0.067.

Once you've merged my current pull request I'll look to continue and apply a fix.

items.title: Inconsistent naming of API key parameter
items.body:
All ``Reader`` objects have the ``api_key`` attribute which stores their API key (when needed). For example, ``get_data_quandl`` (which uses ``QuandlReader``) accepts ``api_key`` as an argument.

However, one must pass ``access_key`` instead of ``api_key`` to ``DataReader``, which may create confusion ([example](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54675413/what-is-wrong-with-the-placement-of-my-api-key/54675521#54675521)).

I think it would be best to rename the ``access_key`` for ``DataReader`` to ``api_key`` to create consistent behavior between itself and all other functions in ``data``. 

One other option would be to change the ``api_key`` attribute to ``access_key`` in all other instances, but this is less reasonable in the interest of POLA.

items.title: Econdb parser
items.body:
I just created a [pull request](https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/pull/615) to include a parser for the [econdb.com](https://www.econdb.com) api. It aggregates datasets from +90 primary sources, including Bank of Japan, China National Bureau of Statistics, or Rosstat.  [Here](https://www.econdb.com/search/#q=""&models.source=true) you can find the complete list of agencies.

Behind the scenes, we have scrapers that extract, clean and process data from the primary sources, and that should save users time in doing the task themselves.

items.title: IEX Default Start is Invalid
items.body: The default start date in the iex "daily.py" module is 1/1/2010, but it is also programmed to give an error if a start date more than five years ago is entered, so if a start date is not provided, the default behavior is to error.  The default start date should be set to be exactly five years ago from the current date, to provide maximum length without error.

items.title: No adjusted values columns from IEX or Yahoo
items.body:
Hello,

I decided to open a new issue, as I realized I was posting in comments about a quite unrelated issue.

If I use the IEX source I can get some data, but there are no adjusted values; I get the following columns:

    date, open, high, low, close, volume

whereas from quandl I was getting 12 columns:

    Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume, Ex-Dividend, Split Ratio, Adj. Open, Adj. High, Adj. Low, Adj. Close, Adj. Volume

If I try Yahoo, as suggested here https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/issues/587#issuecomment-450471265 , I still get only "High, Low, Open, Close, Volume, Adj Close", i.e. I still miss most of the adjusted quantities, and the Ex-Dividend and Split ratio.

Am I missing something, or are the adjusted prices simply not available from IEX or Yahoo?

My question is multi-step:

- how can I get those additional columns using the "yahoo" data source? Is there a way of using the "yahoo" data source AND get the additional columns? If not, why? Can I just infer the adjustment factor from adj_close/close and apply it to the other columns? I am not familiar on whether the different adjusted quantities are adjusted, but from what I understand Ex-dividend and Split ratio are used to determine the adjustment factor: if my reasonment is correct, that one could effectively compute the factor by taking the ratio adj_close/close and then apply it to the other columns. Is that correct?

- for the IEX data source, I don't even get the "adj close", so even if my previous point is OK, with IEX I would have no way of computing the factor. Why? I have briefly looked here: https://pandas-datareader.readthedocs.io/en/latest/readers/iex.html but I could not quite understand if perhaps it's a matter of additional parameters to be set.

- in case adjusted prices are simply not available from Yahoo or IEX, does anyone have a hint on why and on whether is there a source that gives adjusted prices?

Thank you in advance!

items.title: new stooq datareader no longer downloads indices
items.body: The stooq 0.7.0 datareader downloads individual symbols provided as either "AAPL" or "AAPL.US".  But it will no longer download indices (e.g. "^SPX"), and returns an empty dataframe.  Apparently, stooq.py was rewritten to automatically append ".US" in the absence of any other country indicator.  But indices do not take a country indicator (it's "^SPX", not "^SPX.US").  For now, I have simply replaced the new stooq.py with the version 0.6.0 one.  But a fix would be welcome.

items.title: ImmediateDeprecationError of Google Finance data
items.body:
Hello,
I want to get the financial crisis data from 2006 to 2016 of Bank of America.
So i used the following way:--

from pandas_datareader import data, wb
BAC = data.DataReader("BAC", 'google', start, end)

It state error:--
ImmediateDeprecationError: 
Google finance has been immediately deprecated due to large breaks in the API without the
introduction of a stable replacement. Pull Requests to re-enable these data
connectors are welcome.

items.title: mocking/replay-based testing instead of outbound internet usage
items.body:
Hi everybody, I am packaging your software for Gentoo Linux and derivative distributions.
I notice that the distribution strongly discourages relying on network connectivity and production servers for testing. Having read the [“Tests that require network or service access”](https://devmanual.gentoo.org/ebuild-writing/functions/src_test/index.html) section of the documentation, I find this a very sensible approach.

More to the point, in my own experience with this package, this has caused tests to [“dynamically“ break](https://github.com/pydata/pandas-datareader/issues/583#issuecomment-425655790). For the time being I am distributing your package with the test suite disabled. Would you be interested in migrating to a test suite which can better be sandboxed in the future?
